Dear Andy,

I wholeheartedly agree with your comment that concentrated agriculture frees up land for biodiversity.

In "Letters from the Dust Bowl", Caroline Henderson describes their 1912 wheat harvest . Yield:12 bushels per acre, right on average for all of Oklahoma that year.

And the land was so intensively used that buffalo, white-tailed deer, cougar, beaver, bald eagles and a long list of wildlife had basically been wiped off the face of the state.

One hundred years later, in 2012, Oklahoma's wheat harvest averaged 36 bushels per acre. Exactly triple what Caroline Henderson managed in 1912.

And 2012 was a drought year. In good years I hear reports of 50 to 56 bushels per acre.

And this astonishing productivity means that much farmland can be allowed to return to nature. My family has three such parcels of fallow farmland totalling 330 acres.

So now the deer are back, in greater numbers even than before white settlement in 1889. The cougar are back, too, chasing the deer. The beaver are back (to my sorrow, since they are cutting down the trees on my Osage County acreage).

And the bald eagles are back. Last weekend my family was thrilled to sight five bald eagles (FIVE!!!) in one tree 100 yards south of Highway 60 near Shidler, OK.

I should point out that the greatest threat to those eagles is now the projected wind farm planned for installation within sight of the tree upon which those eagles were perched.

The Laffer curve is a hill, not a monotonic slope. Laffer said that there is an optimum taxation rate that will maximize revenue. If you are on the right side of that optimum, then tax rates are too high and cutting them will lead to higher tax revenues, but if you are on the left side of that optimum, then raising tax rates will increase tax revenues.

The right wing (conveniently) assumes that we are on the right side of the Laffer hill, and so cutting tax rates will lead to higher tax revenues. The left should have read up on the Laffer curve, recognized that it's a hill and not a steady slope, and countered that the response to various right-wing tax cuts has demonstrated that we are on the left side of the Laffer hill, and if we want to raise revenues, then we need to raise tax rates. Instead, the left demonized Laffer and his curve, and the truly important question -- what is the optimum tax rate? -- has been ignored.

To give some credit to Mr. Laffer, the problem with his infamous curve isn't the concept that at some point high taxes actually do push the heavily taxed to become less productive. The problem is that people have latched onto this concept to claim that lowering taxes is good, when historical evidence shows that the actual breakeven point is a tax rate above 70% on the wealthy. So I wonder how much of the misuse of the Laffer Curve is due to Mr. Laffer's misrepresentation of it, and how much is the panderers to the rich twisting a concept to suit their own ends. The right wing has a rich history of misrepresenting other people's ideas to further their own agenda.

Sometimes what one may initially believe is a "common cold" is actually a much more serious condition and, although I am not a physician, the solution you propose reminds me of the old adage, "a physician who treats himself has a fool for a patient."
Several years back I was preparing for a trip to Florida, but was suffering from lingering congestion and a persistent cough.; symptoms which may be associated with a "common cold."
As a precaution, prompted by my nagging wife, I visited my PCP.
After a simple exam he recommended chest x-rays and I told him I would do this as soon as I returned from Florida; he stated emphatically I should have the x-rays as soon as possible and the diagnosis was that I had pleural effusion, a condition that leads to the build up of fluids surrounding the lungs.
Prior to the procedure to remove the excess fluid my condition worsened to the point where when I tried to get out of bed it felt as if I was being stabbed in the chest and I could only walk about 10 feet without being out of breath.
Had I ignored his advice and travelled to Florida there is a good chance I would suffered from a collapsed lung or worse.
My point is if did not have reasonable coverage I probably would not have visited my PCP; and once the pain generated by the pleural effusion was so great I would have wound up in the ER and aside from increasing my overall medical costs I may have suffered irreparable physical damage.
Sometimes a doctors visit pays off.

Co-pays and deductibles address any problem of a consumer being too quick to run to the doctor; there is no need to set up people, whatever their health and situation, to the vagaries of a unregulated free health market.

"prompted by my nagging wife"

Where would any man be without a "nagging" wife? Nowhere.

I am regretfully convinced, being one, that males are inferior in most ways and in most activities to women. I joke not.

If Mr. Reinhardt disagrees, he should ask his wife her opinion.

John, your definition is correct, but your application in the healthcare debate is quite faulty especially because in healthcare prices frequently have little rhyme or reason.

You said " Healthcare is a product for which the demand is more or less infinite, and inelastic. "

There is debate about how much elasticity exists in healthcare, but I find it impossible not to believe that much of healthcare is elastic. I believe some like to pretend that healthcare is inelastic solely to promote their ideological beliefs not born out in reality.

Consider the elasticity that exists for an office visit when a patient has a simple cold. If the price of an office visit is free a lot of people will request one. As the price goes up the requests fall. Most encounters for physician services fall into that type of category, elastic.

The question of elasticity of any goods or services in health care is made even more confusing because healthcare prices frequently have little rhyme or reason and the one receiving the care frequently is not the one paying for it. Thus doubling the price paid by someone else is meaningless to the one receiving the service.

Laffer is actually right about that one. Study from Harvard came out today showing that expansion of Medicaid increases rather than decreases ER visits , totally undercutting one of the principal reasons offered for the Affordable Care Act http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/01/02/study-expandi...

"You can't give away health care and not expect the system to overuse it." This sort of cartoonish talk is what continues to make genuine dialogue impossible.
Progressives acknowledge problems with the ACA. Conservatives caricature it rather than offering their solutions for those problems. No discussion.

Are the liberals so feeble politically and in the media that the only way they can get a persuasive word edgewise in the public venue is to force their views on others via a government-based ruling?

You have room for all the “diversity and competition” of opinion you may wish to have; what you really want is to FORCE your views on others. You use the word “allow,” while the word coerce by the FCC would be more appropriate.

Of the multitude of popular TV channels, Fox is the only normatively-Conservative one; all the rest are liberal to one extent or another. Don’t you guys on the Left have any sense of irony and embarrassment?
I don't want them here in England - please keep them there where I can laugh at them from afar!

Mike, you are right about O'Reilly and Limbaugh - they would be laughed at in England, as being right wing 'loonies'.
Actually, apart from Hyde Park Corner, they would not be given airtime on radio or TV, as news and current affairs programmes have to be 'balanced and fair' by statute - Fox News would not be licenced over here.

At certain times in a country's history, it becomes easier to promote hatred and stupidity than love and understanding. We can point to O'Reilly and Limbaugh, but the worrisome part is their large audiences. Had Americans been able to continue our intellectual traditions, those buffoons would move to England, warbling away atop a cardboard box in Hyde Park.

The best single thing we could do would be to make the FCC return to its charter and allow the return of diversity and competition to our media. Other institutions such as schools and government agencies are frightened and weak. With a vigorous and courageous press, the people might awaken. We better, because our leaders won't.

Dear Mr. George,

Another thought on why Easter Island is a poor proof of Malthus's hypothesis.

Jacob Roggeween visted Easter Island in 1722 and found several thousand inhabitants, happy and prosperous, with large fields of potatoes and chickens "everywhere".

James Cook visited Easter Island in 1774 and found the island "poor, barren and inhospitable, for the only fresh food they could discover was a few pounds of potatoes and a few scraggy chickens." Deserted farms, deserted villages, ruins of old harbor installations were in evidence.

So Easter Island society collapsed between 1722 and 1774.

Why?

Native tradition tells of a bloody civil war. Recent theories include the depredations an exploding population of rats from off Roggeween's ships. Nobody knows for sure.

But one thing is certain: Easter Island's climate has not changed for better or worse but it has never been forested. So the islanders who settled there could not build new ships when the ones that carried them to the island succumbed to age and ship-worm.

An island people who loses the ability to make sea-going shipping becomes, in effect, prisoners on that island. They thus abandon a key factor in the adaptability that brought them to the island in the first place.

So did the Easter Islanders suffer from resource shortage? I think not. Rather, a fundamental error in judgment and public policy.

I always think weather related criticism of any mayor of any city should be taken with a grain of salt. Granted there are cases of flat out incompetence, poor decision making...when the previous mayor of Atlantic City defied NJ governor orders to evacuate during Sandy. That said, for the most part weather happens, governments do the best they can..Mayors, county commissioners..the only thing they really can do is keep services well funded and stocked with good managers to keep it well organized. A Mayor may happen to be out of town when a storm hits, that doesn't say anything. de Blasio himself, nothing that goes wrong should be blamed on him considering it's not even a full first week that he's been in office. Pundits, critics..will try to find anything to put on their opponents ...this includes both left and right.

Relating to the weather itself.. the snow while a lot is not the main problem. It's the cold. Below 20 degree salt stops working as well, below 10 it stops working altogether. Conditions become dangerous with people so use to salt working in normal temperatures of 20+. People should stay inside. Perhaps some volunteers can organize to try to get the homeless into shelters until the cold snap lets up.

Other than that, I wish new infrastructure spending would create solar powered heating systems for roads so we wouldn't have to use as much salt..which washes away into fresh water supplies causing environmental harm to the local ecosystem.

Once TV weather reporting morphed into entertainment programming, the door was left wide-open to sensationalist forecasting. During winter months, telegenic weatherpersons appear to pull snow out of the sky in order to generate higher ratings. During warmer seasons, they are routinely sent into harm's way such as exposed ocean front beaches with fearsome Atlantic hurricanes bearing down on them. Then, with microphones clutched in drenched hands, they personally inform us how powerful wind and water currents really are as they are buffeted off their feet. It's amazing that one of them hasn't yet died in the line of duty in order to "bring us the story" of bad weather on a first-person basis. Enough is enough!. The 24 hour news cycle has destroyed much of the professionalism of televised weather forecasting.

Now I remember, Councilman Dan Halloran leveled those same accusations, a Tea Party occult religion follower later indicted for bribery in the Smith case, and investigated for engaging in hanky panky with two of his council interns.

The photo of the Brooklyn Bridge in the snow is breathtaking.

They were plowing all night in my midtown neighborhood, but it was tough to keep the streets clean with the wind and extreme cold. Even now, the avenues are black but not dry.

Wish others would be as diligent as the mayor in shoveling their sidewalks.

The wind-chill factor is essentially bogus.

It's of little significance for any adequately clothed part of your body, and its reliance on temperature as a unit of reference is unscientific. The media should stop referring to it. See these two articles:

http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/recycled/2008/12/wind_ch...

http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Rough-Weather-The-Misused-Wind-Chill-...

As the article in "Slate" observes, "The weathermen trot out these arctic, pumped-down numbers to put an exclamation point on the banality of winter. "

It would be interesting to learn in what other countries the media make the mistake of invoking the wind-chill factor. It is sometimes mentioned in Canada, but with much less emphasis than occurs here.
Dorothy, the ships in the Antarctic are stuck because of blizzard winds pushing the sea ice around the ships, not because there's so much more snow/ice than normal for the Antarctic summer.
